_prev_prog_3.TR_OtherType: Periodic monthly training calls given by the Corporate Refrigeration Team

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

C&S Wholesale Grocers LLC's senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but to also maintain a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding community.  The Corporate Compliance Team administers the facility's safety and environmental policies.  The Corporate Compliance Team periodically evaluates the health and safety practices of facility employees to ensure compliance, and oversees implementation of the safety and environmental programs.  These programs include forklift safety, hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturer's documentation, Emergency Action, as well as the Risk Management Plan.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

Dubois Logistics is located at 851 Beaver Road in Dubois, PA.  The primary business of Dubois Logistics is to provide refrigerated warehousing and storage for various food products.  In order to conduct operations, the facility maintains a refrigeration system containing approximately 16,274 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance.  The refrigeration system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, and then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for glycol chilling, dock operations, cold/freezer storage, and ice making.  

Off-site Release Scenarios
C&S has conducted an OCA based on the EPA document titled "RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidelines," and used the EPA's RMP*Comp to estimate the distance traveled to a toxic endpoint defined by the EPA regulation. This data were then used to estimate the potential impact caused by a release from each of the regulated substances.
Worst-Case Release Scenarios
As required by regulations, scenarios w

ere considered where the entire capacity of the largest vessel for each regulated chemical at the facility was released in 10 minutes. Although these scenarios are highly unlikely in the event of a release, it provides the local responding agencies with a maximum possible impact in the event of an accidental release. In considering these releases, the most pessimistic meteorological conditions were used. Passive mitigation measures were taken into account when considering these release scenarios.
Alternative Release Scenarios
Alternative scenarios were developed to assess what potential impact may occur in the event of a release that is more likely to occur than the worst-case scenarios for each of the regulated chemicals. Several possible release scenarios were considered, and the scenarios with the greatest offsite impact were chosen. In considering the alternative release scenario, the default meteorological conditions for alternative scenarios were used in RMP*Comp. These scenarios represent a more realistic release, and have a downwind distance and impact considerably smaller than the worst-case scenario. No passive or active mitigation measures were taken into account when considering these release scenarios.

Process Description

The High Pressure Receiver is a horizontal vessel that maintains a reservoir of liquid ammonia that is supplied by liquid injection to cool the compressor lubrication oil. The liquid is pumped to the compressors, where the heat from the oil partially boils the ammonia and causes the vapor to return to the High Pressure Receiver. The High Pressure Receiver supplies high pressure liquid to the High Temperature Accumulator and the Low Temperature Accumulator.

The High Temperature Accumulator serves as a suction accumulator and pumps liquid ammonia to the Banana Room, Produce, Wet Produce, Dairy/Deli, Meat, Candy Room, and Dock Evaporators. The High Temperature Accumulator also collects the liquid/vapor mixture produced by these evapora

tors; the vapor returned is then drawn to the compressors.

The Low Temperature Accumulator pumps liquid ammonia to the 0ºF Freezer and the -10ºF Freezer Evaporators. The Low Temperature Accumulator also collects the liquid/vapor mixture produced by these evaporators; the vapor returned is then drawn to the compressors.

The evaporators maintain the appropriate room temperatures by transferring heat from the air in the room to the ammonia inside the coils, using fans to move air across the coils. The result is (partially) vaporized ammonia that is returned to both the High Temperature and Low Temperature Accumulator vessels.

The Glycol Heat Exchanger transfers heat from the ammonia vapor to the glycol solution, which heats the glycol solution. The glycol is used for under floor heating in a separate closed system.

The compressors (RC1 thru RC4) draw the suction return vapor that is collected in the High Temperature and Low Temperature Accumulator vessels and compresses it to discharge high pressure vapor (hot gas). The compressors are the primary energy input into the system. Hot gas is used internally within the system to assist with defrosting the evaporator coils based on a timed cycle. The main high stage discharge flow is routed to the Condensers, which discharge the latent heat in the ammonia to the atmosphere using sprayed water and fans, resulting in high pressure liquid ammonia. This liquid is recycled into the High Pressure Receiver vessel.

The system also incorporates an automatic purger. Ammonia in the system is automatically purged of any non-condensables, i.e., air and water vapor. Non-condensables are purged from the condensers and the High Pressure Receiver. The purged gases are removed from the system through the auto purger bubbler, and the collected ammonia vapor returns to the Low Temperature Accumulator.

Ammonia sensors are located in the Engine Room and within refrigerated spaces throughout the perishable and freezer warehouse.

ACCIDENTAL

RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

In order to operate the ammonia refrigeration system, the facility complies with the following risk management regulations:
1) OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM); and
2) EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP).

These regulations impose numerous requirements on the facility to ensure the safety of the public and on-site workers.  The following summarizes the key compliance programs that have been implemented by Dubois Logistics to prevent the accidental release of ammonia from the facility.  The Operating Procedures program ensures that the ammonia system is operated in a safe manner.  The Training program ensures that personnel fully understand how to perform their jobs in a safe manner.  The Mechanical Integrity program ensures that the ammonia system is in proper working condition based upon routine testing, inspections, and maintenance according to manufacturer's specifications and industry standards.  The Management of Change program ensures that process modifications are implemented in a safe manner.  The Pre-Startup Safety Review program ensures that adequate safety measures are in place before ammonia is introduced into a process.  The Hot Work Permit program ensures that Dubois Logistics' employees and contractors perform hot work (e.g. welding) in a safe manner.  The Contractor Safety program ensures that contractors understand the hazards of ammonia and must take specified precautions to safely complete job requirements.

It is important to note that the refrigeration system has been designed with several safety features to prevent the accidental release of ammonia.  For example, the compressors are equipped with safety mechanisms that will cause the units to shut down if operating conditions exceed designated safety limits.  Also, level indicators, alarms, and switches are installed in key points within the system to monitor the supply of liquid ammonia and to ensure that a vessel is not

overfilled.  The facility has also installed ammonia sensors in the Engine Room, in the cold storage areas which will alert operators in the event of an ammonia detection. 

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no federally reportable incidents nor any that resulted in serious injuries or offsite consequences within the last five years (April 2019 - April 2024). 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility has an Emergency Action Plan (plan) in effect at the facility.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives: 
 
- save lives;
- minimize and avoid injuries;
- protect the environment; and
- minimize property damage.

The Plan provides the notification procedures and evacuation routes for emergencies that may arise at the facility. The Facility is non-responding and has personnel trained to support the HazMat response team if required (up to 300 ppm of ammonia).

There is a specific program (CEHS-0042) which outlines the training, qualifications and procedures for authorized ammonia Incident responders and observers.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations.  

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

In 1996, the refrigeration system was thoroughly examined for safety hazards by way of a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA).  In addition, five Revalidations of the initial Process Hazard Analysis have been conducted.  

	1st Revalidation: 1999 
	2nd Revalidation: 2004
	3rd Revalidation: 2009
	4th Revalidation: August 2010
	5th Revalidation: August 2015 
        6th Revalidation: August 2020

The PHA Revalidations consisted of a combination of the following methodologies:
- Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study
- What-If Studies
- series of safety checklists; and
- facility inspection.

The mitigation measures (recommendations) include additional training, key maintenance-related tests/inspection, and enhanced emergency response policies and procedures.
